articles.title: Test 1
articles.name: test1_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content: The file named test 1 is a building next to the university oval stadium. This building is a feature without any textures because the cityGML export is a geometry export. The master json is named test1_geometry. I must delete this file because we can have the textures now.

articles.title: Test 2
articles.name: test2_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content: The file named test 2 is all the buildings of the university. These buildings are gather in one feature without any textures because the cityGML export is a geometry export. The master json is named test2_geometry. I must delete this file because we can have the textures and multi features now.

articles.title: Test 3
articles.name: test3_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content: The file named test 3 is some buildings in Berlin, Germany. These buildings are several features with textures because the cityGML export is a collada/Gltf export. The master json is named test3_collada. I must keep this file because it works very well.

articles.title: Berlin
articles.name: example_city_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content: The file named Berlin is some buildings in Berlin, Germany. These buildings are several features with textures because the cityGML export is a collada/Gltf export. The master json is named berlin1_collada. I must keep this file because it works very well.

articles.title: Mini Berlin
articles.name: miniberlin_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content: The file named Mini Berlin is few buildings in Berlin, Germany. These buildings are several features with textures because the cityGML export is a collada/Gltf export. The master json is named miniberlin_collada. I must keep this file because it works very well.

articles.title: Mini Uni
articles.name: miniuni_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content: The file named Mini Uni is a single building of the university. These buildings are several features with textures because the cityGML export is a collada/Gltf export. The master json is named miniunimelb_collada. I must keep this file because it works very well.

articles.title: Description of the App
articles.name: demo1_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content:
This app demonstrates how land development proposal assessments can be improved through the use of 3D open models such as IFC and CityGML. 
Spatial representation of land development proposals is often submitted in 2D paper/image/CAD formats. The 2D design of even complex high-rise land developments is a norm. Moreover, land development assessments are applied in isolation since the responsible agencies usually do not have the infrastructure that enables sharing spatial data and automating the assessment process.

articles.title: Description of the App
articles.name: demo2_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content: This app demonstrates the use of 3d modelling for the visualisation of potential built form envelopes based on the applicable planning controls. Together with major urban renewal precincts, areas around traffic corridors and activity centres are being rezoned and redeveloped to meet Melbourneâ€™s growing population needs. Such changes are increasing the importance of effective urban planning design to achieve development outcomes that meet community expectations. Complex planning controls need to be communicated in an easily accessible and visual format.

articles.title: Description of the App
articles.name: demo3_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content: This app demonstrates a sensor information infrastructure for the Parkville campus of the University of Melbourne. Buildings of the campus are connected to sensory devices and the sensor observation are made available in real-time. The project publishes the sensor data in open standards so other application domains can make use of the data.

articles.title: Description of the App
articles.name: demo4_collada_MasterJSON
articles.content: The aim of this app is to improve the interoperability of the IFC and CityGML standards. The use of 3D data in the industries of public administration, architecture, engineering and construction has increased over recent years. With this increased use of spatial data, a number of different standards have emerged.
